etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Palladius' De Re Rustica. From Spanish esparto esparto or its etymon classical Latin spartum esparto, Spanish broom, a rope made of this

definitions: Any of several Mediterranean plants yielding fibres used to produce cords, coarse cloth, paper, etc.; specifically esparto, Stipa tenacissima and Lygeum spartum, and Spanish broom, Spartium junceum.

etymologies: early 17th century. Variant of sprat, with metathesis

definitions: Any of various coarse rushes or grasses.
